titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Rockefeller University records, Index Cards FA1068

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-03-09 00:00:34 -0500.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: All Rockefeller University collection titles are preceded by the term Rockefeller University records (unless otherwise noted)
Former Classification is provided following the current title.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Index cards are arranged alphabetically by personal or institutional name or subject.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The original index cards are physically available on-site at RAC.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: All index cards are presented in this finding aid as PDF digital objects. See each file level entry for applicable content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Use of the card index to the Rockefeller University collections ---
There are three elements that compose each card.
At the top of each card appears as personal or institutional name or subject.
Below the name or subject appears a description of the material indexed. A given entry may describe a collection, a file, or one or more items.
At the left side of the card appear filing information. For example, 190 (1) signifies the formerly classified record group 190, Box 1. (1) 14 signifies Box 1, Folder 14.
The cards bear Record Group numbers, such as 450 H735. The use of these numbers and their associated classification system have been discontinued by RAC.

Please see the "Other Finding Aids" note placed in the Access and Use Information at the top level of this finding aid. Within this "Other Finding Aids" note you will find a listing of all Rockefeller University holdings along with the current Finding Aid Number (FA#), correlated former classification number, and hyperlinks which facilitate access to all ther finding aids that are currently open for research. The former classification number is also provided in the "File Plan" note of each individual finding aid.
The Finding Aid number (FA#), and associated finding aid hyperlinks, can be used to locate material through the RAC DIMES website and request records and papers.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Rockefeller University, established in 1901 by John D. Rockefeller as The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, was the first institution in the United States devoted solely to biomedical research. The earliest work was carried on through grants-in-aid to researchers in various American, and a few European, laboratories, but that program was phased out after the Institute's own laboratories were opened on its New York City campus in 1906. In 1954, the Institute became part of the University of the State of New York and acquired the right to confer graduate degrees, awarding its first Ph.D. in 1959. The Institute became The Rockefeller University in 1965.

The University archives delineate the growth of research programs which from the beginning were aimed at developing fundamental knowledge of disease and physiology. Research is carried out in interdisciplinary laboratories headed by leading scientists, who were known for more than fifty years as Members of the Institute and subsequently as Professors. A hospital was opened in 1910 and has remained an integral part of the research program.

Many Rockefeller University scientists have been recognized for excellence in their respective fields. As of 2014, 24 Rockefeller University associated scientists have received Nobel Prizes, fourteen scientists have been awarded the National Medal of Science, and 21 have received the Albert Lasker Medical Research Award.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The RU index cards were created as a reference tool in the 1960s by the Rockefeller University library staff initially in charge of the RU Archives. The cards included name, subject, and archival collection headings. Two identical sets of catalog cards were maintained, one at the Archives Office, on campus and the other at the Rockefeller Archive Center, to which most of the RU Archives' records were transferred, starting in the mid-1970s. The RU index card catalog was maintained until 1990, at which time all collection description was created in standard archival finding aids. Despite the end date for this catalog system, the item-level description of the materials in the RU Archives makes it an important reference resource for scholars.
